_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY 

Loganbill Ag Services

600 Highway 5

Syracuse, Missouri



 

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES: 

 

Loganbill Ag Services, has an excellent record in preventing and minimizing releases of anhydrous ammonia (hereafter, anhydrous ammonia will be referred to as ammonia).

 

There are provisions for coordination with outside agencies, such as with the Fortuna Fire Protection District in the event of an emergency. We are also prepared to work with and coordinate with other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment. 



Passive release prevention efforts include placement of storage tanks, and barriers to vehicular traffic making contact with the tanks.  All bulk storage tanks are located where they are unlikely to be struck by vehicles. 

 

Active prevention measures include inspection of all tanks at least annually.  All required repairs are completed when noted or prior to further use.  

 

Emergency response policies are as described below. 

 

FACILITY DESCRIPTION AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED: 

 

This facility is located north of the intersection of Highway 5 and 50 in Morgan County near Syracuse, Missouri, and supplies anhydrous ammonia to farmers.  The primary activity at the facility is the receiving, storage and distribution of anhydrous ammonia for direct application as a crop nutrient. 

 

   The maximum quantity stored would be just over 280,000 pounds in each of our 3 tanks with a 60,000 gallon storage capability. The maximum quantity handled would be the unloading of a transport delivery truck holding approximately 50,000 pounds. 

 

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS: 

 

The facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1, 1989", published by The American National 

Standards Institute, Inc., and the standard

s of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and handling of Anhydrous Ammonia". 



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY: 

 

There are no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that: have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; nor to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage. 

 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM: 

 

Employees will notify the fire protection district in the event of a major release.  The location Manager and other designated employees are authorized to take appropriate actions to stop small releases by shutting off valves, etc.  Other employees will notify the fire protection district, and evacuate the area as necessary.  There is a written emergency response plan 

in place that is for the use of, and applies only to, company employees.  This plan includes evacuation procedures, who is authorized to take emergency actions to control a release, notification and alarm procedures, and other necessary information. 



The facility has; 

 

   a. a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA Standard, 29 CFR 1910.38; 

 

   b. provided State and Local authorities with the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA); 

 

   c. a written emergency response program, in accordance with OSHA Standard, 29 CFR 1910.120, including pre-emergency planning and employee training. 

 

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY: 

 

Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility. Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. There are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations for implementation at this time.
